NEWS-LETTER

Famous Tenor Set
For SC Bunny Fete
Tenor Joseph Laderoute, whom
The New York Times called "a
first rate artist" will perform before the Easter Assembly of the
Student Council in Shriver Hall
at 10 a.m., on April 1.
Mr. Laderoute, who, earlier in
the year, addressed the Hopkins
Cosmopolitan Club, has performed
in every major city of the United
States and has appeared in concert, recital, opera, and oratorio.
He has also done radio, TV and recording work. A member of the
faculty of the Peabody Conservatory, the tenor has a repetoire of
forty oratorios, twenty-nine operas
and over five-hundred songs. Assembly Chairman Jim Pessin
stated, "We do not yet know what
his program will be for our assembly; however, I can guarantee it
will be a good one."
Mr. Laderoute is a descendant of
the Ojibway Indian tribe and
started his career twenty eight
years ago, at the age of five, and
was once guest soloist of the Paul-

However, this year an exceptionally large number of keys and
stars will be awarded to juniors,
Habermann added.
Lists of members and officers of
the various SAC activities were
submitted during the first semester and the SAC has worked
for several months to decide who
will receive the awards, Habermann 'continued. The date for the
presentation of the awards is not
certain at present, but will probably be some time at the end of
April.

ist Choristers. Since his youth,
Laderoute has appeared before
such conductors as Sir Thomas
Beecham of the London Royal Philharmonic, Serge Koussevitzky of
the Boston Symphony, Charles
Munch of the New York Philharmonic, Eugene Ormandy of the
NBC Symphohy, and Arturo Toscannini, of the NBC Symphony. He
is presently residing in Baltimore
with his wife and six children.

Spring Dance
Off-Yakubisin
Jay Yakubisin, President of the
Cotillion Board, announced this
week that there will be no Spring
Cotillion on April 2 as was scheduled.
A substitute event such as a jazz
concert was considered, but it, too,
was rejected.
The main reason for the dropping of the usual spring social
sponsored by the Cotillion Board
was the loss suffered from the poor
attendance at the Junior Prom
which was co-sponsored with the
Junior Class.
The fact that the Military Ball
is slated for this weekend also influenced the Cotillion Board's decision. Although it is formal, it
was felt that the ROTC event
would sufficiently decrease the _demand for a dance the following
weekend to cause another poor
turn-out.

Homewood, Baltimore, March 25, 1955

WUS Week April 25-29;
Ugly Man ContestPlanned
April 25-29 will be World University Service Week on the Hopkins campus. During the week a
fund-raising campaign will be conducted here for the international
educational charity organization.
Paul Niebanck and E. J. Johnson, co-chairmen of WUS's Special
Events Committee, announced this
week that an Ugly Man contest
and a Special Dinner with a prominent speaker are planned for the
drive.
Another special event in the
planning stage is an auction on
Friday, April 29, at which dates

Veterans Attempt •
To Organize Group
An attempt to form an undergraduate veterans organization
has just been initiated by a group
of ex-G.I.'s at Homewood, according to Bill Keller, a Hopkins freshman and a former G.I.
In an effort to aid the veterans
on the Hopkins campus, the primary purpose of this proposed
organization will be to provide
orientation of incoming veterans,
a clarification of veterans benefits,
informal tutoring, and extracurricular activities, according to
Keller.
All veterans at Hopkins interested in this organization are requested to drop a note to Mr.
Hacketts, P.O. Box 1061.

Debate CouncilElects New SC Constitution
President his Snag,Says Smith
Willer New

The Hopkins Debate Council has
elected its officers for the coming
year and has scheduled three collegiate debates and a television appearance during the next few
Weeks.
Reuben Lee, president of the Debate Council, announced that the
Council's officers for the 1955-56
term have been elected. They are:
Herbie Butler, president; Lou
Sank, first vice-president; Earl
Baker, second vice-president; Larry
Wolf, recording secretary, and
Les Norins, corresponding secretary.
Two Hopkins debators, Larry
Wolf and Les Norins, will travel
to Washington College at Chestertown to participate in a forum on
China, March 25. During their
Part of the program they will engage the Eastern Shoremen in a
debate on the National Debating
Council topic: "Resolved that the
United States Should Extend Diplomatic Recognition to the CornMunist Government of China."

"I like a job that keeps me jumping,"
says Bill Jermain, C.E. from Marquette,
'52: "And my first management assignment with Wisconsin Telephone Company does just that. I'm Service
Foreman at Sheboygan,with nine installers, and that means variety of responsibility. But judge for yourself. Here's
a quick run-down of what I did yesterday, on a typical day8:10—"Checked day's work schedule.
One of my new men was putting in a
buried service wire, and I went over the
job specs with him to be sure he had
things straight.
8:30 —"Answered mail while my clerk
checked time sheets from previous day.
9:30 —"Out to supervise installation of
the first aluminum Outdoor Telephone
Booth in my exchange. Reviewed the
assembly instructions with the installers,
then arranged for special tools and bolts
to be delivered to the job.

11:30 —"Drove across town. Made a
complete 'quality inspection' on a telephone we installed last week. Everything
checked O.K.
12:00 —"Lunch.
1:00 —"Picked up film for next day's
safety meeting. Watched the film, made
notes for discussion.
2:00—"Met with moving company

manager to estimate cost of telephone
cable lifting for a house moving job.
Drove the route he had planned and
worked out schedule for construction
crews.
3:30—"Returned to aluminum booth in-

stallation. Went over wiring specs with
the electrician.
4:00 —"Stopped at Central Office to
pick up next day's orders. Met installers
at garage as they checked in and assigned
next day's work."

Bill has been in his present job about a year, and is
looking forward to new responsibilities as his experience increases...as are the many young college
men who have chosen telephone careers. If you'd be
interested in a similar opportunity with a Bell telephone company... or with Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric or Sandia Corporation...see
your Placement Officer for full details.

Homewood, Baltimore, March 25, 19S(

Jay Stickmen Face W-L, Duke
In Scrimmages This Week

BIA

The Board of Intramural Athletics has installed two post
pffice boxes so that the students will have a convenient method of
giving score sheets and other information to the Board.
One of the boxes is located in the basement of Gilman Hall
next to the BIA bulletin board, and the other box is located in the
gymnasium. The Board can also be informed through PO
2345, in the new dorm.
FRATERNITY SOFTBALL

Alpha Tau Omega, led by Phil Kirol, beat Phi Epsilon Pi,
9 to 5 last week, in the fraternity softball season's opener.
Kirol had two home runs, one with the bases loaded. Herb
Cohen, with three hits in five attempts, was the standout of the
Phi Ep team.
In the other fraternity softzall game, Phi Sig walloped KA,
6 to' O. Ty Freeman, who holds Phi Sig's chances for Wittich
Trophy retirement, was in his usual fine pitching form.
INDEPENDENT SOFTBALL

Sam Hemphill's outstanding hurling led the Ding-Dongs to
victory in their first game last week, as the Ding-Dongs shut out
the Demons, 4 to 0.
In the other fraternity softball game, Phi Sig walloped KA,
hitting, one home run being included among his four safeties,
sparked the Misfits to an 11 to 1 win over the Black and Blues.
RinumualmsaTy TRACK MEET _
Jack Sutherland, president of the Spiked Shoe Society,
announced early this week the results of the Society's annual
intramural track meeet.
Lou Kady, in 11 seconds flat, won the 100-yard dash;
Robin Kaples took the 220-yard run in 24 seconds; and Pinkney
Holmes captured first placse in the 660-yard set—to in 1.34.8.
Al Hynes ran the 120-yard low hurdles in 16.4 seconds. Jack
Carloek rounded out the track events by running the mile in
5:42.8.
In the field events, Jim Love won the discus throw with a
heave of 108' 7.5"; Clayton Emory leaped five feet to win the
high jump; George Laubaek took the broad jump with an effort
of 17' 8.5"; and Love repeated in the shot put with a throw
of 36'1".

become a part of the permanent

A student who wishes to drop a
course should get the signatures of
the adviser, the instructor and the
Dean on a Course Change form,
then file it at the Registrar's Office.
The deadline for filing course
changes is Tuesday, April 12; the
place is the Registrar's Office,
Shriver Hall. Even though an informal F is reported a student may
drop a course on or before April
12 without penalty; a student will
receive an F if he drops a course
after April 12, whether he has
been given an Informal F or not.
Special problems should be taken
up with the adviser, the Dean or
the Registrar.

Famous Tenor Set
For SC Bunny Fete
Tenor Joseph Laderoute, whom
The New York Times called "a
first rate artist" will perform before the Easter Assembly of the
Student Council in Shriver Hall
at 10 a.m., on April 1.
Mr. Laderoute, who, earlier in
the year, addressed the Hopkins
Cosmopolitan Club, has performed
in every major city of the United
States and has appeared in concert, recital, opera, and oratorio.
He has also done radio, TV and recording work. A member of the
faculty of the Peabody Conservatory, the tenor has a repetoire of
forty oratorios, twenty-nine operas
and over five-hundred songs. Assembly Chairman Jim Pessin
stated, "We do not yet know what
his program will be for our assembly; however, I can guarantee it
will be a good one."
Mr. Laderoute is a descendant of
the Ojibway Indian tribe and
started his career twenty eight
years ago, at the age of five, and
was once guest soloist of the Paul-

ehairman of the Honor Commission are also eligible for keys.
Stars are awarded for holding
an office or having two years' membership in another activity besides
the one for which the key was
given.
Most of the Certificates are
awarded to juniors, and most of
the keys and stars go to seniors.
However, this year an exceptionally large number of keys and
stars will be awarded to juniors,
Habermann added.
Lists of members and officers of
the various SAC activities were
submitted during the first semester and the SAC has worked
for several months to decide who
will receive the awards, Habermann 'continued. The date for the
presentation of the awards is not
certain at present, but will probably be some time at the end of
April.

ist Choristers. Since his youth,
Laderoute has appeared before
such conductors as Sir Thomas
Beecham of the London Royal Philharmonic, Serge Koussevitzky of
the Boston Symphony, Charles
Munch of the New York Philharmonic, Eugene Ormandy of the
NBC Symphohy, and Arturo Toscannini, of the NBC Symphony. He
is presently residing in Baltimore
with his wife and six children.

Spring Dance
Off-Yakubisin
Jay Yakubisin, President of the
Cotillion Board, announced this
week that there will be no Spring
Cotillion on April 2 as was scheduled.
A substitute event such as a jazz
concert was considered, but it, too,
was rejected.
The main reason for the dropping of the usual spring social
sponsored by the Cotillion Board
was the loss suffered from the poor
attendance at the Junior Prom
which was co-sponsored with the
Junior Class.
The fact that the Military Ball
is slated for this weekend also influenced the Cotillion Board's decision. Although it is formal, it
was felt that the ROTC event
would sufficiently decrease the _demand for a dance the following
weekend to cause another poor
turn-out.

Homewood, Baltimore, March 25, 1955

WUS Week April 25-29;
Ugly Man ContestPlanned
April 25-29 will be World University Service Week on the Hopkins campus. During the week a
fund-raising campaign will be conducted here for the international
educational charity organization.
Paul Niebanck and E. J. Johnson, co-chairmen of WUS's Special
Events Committee, announced this
week that an Ugly Man contest
and a Special Dinner with a prominent speaker are planned for the
drive.
Another special event in the
planning stage is an auction on
Friday, April 29, at which dates

Veterans Attempt •
To Organize Group
An attempt to form an undergraduate veterans organization
has just been initiated by a group
of ex-G.I.'s at Homewood, according to Bill Keller, a Hopkins freshman and a former G.I.
In an effort to aid the veterans
on the Hopkins campus, the primary purpose of this proposed
organization will be to provide
orientation of incoming veterans,
a clarification of veterans benefits,
informal tutoring, and extracurricular activities, according to
Keller.
All veterans at Hopkins interested in this organization are requested to drop a note to Mr.
Hacketts, P.O. Box 1061.

The Hopkins Debate Council has
elected its officers for the coming
year and has scheduled three collegiate debates and a television appearance during the next few
Weeks.
Reuben Lee, president of the Debate Council, announced that the
Council's officers for the 1955-56
term have been elected. They are:
Herbie Butler, president; Lou
Sank, first vice-president; Earl
Baker, second vice-president; Larry
Wolf, recording secretary, and
Les Norins, corresponding secretary.
Two Hopkins debators, Larry
Wolf and Les Norins, will travel
to Washington College at Chestertown to participate in a forum on
China, March 25. During their
Part of the program they will engage the Eastern Shoremen in a
debate on the National Debating
Council topic: "Resolved that the
United States Should Extend Diplomatic Recognition to the CornMunist Government of China."

"I like a job that keeps me jumping,"
says Bill Jermain, C.E. from Marquette,
'52: "And my first management assignment with Wisconsin Telephone Company does just that. I'm Service
Foreman at Sheboygan,with nine installers, and that means variety of responsibility. But judge for yourself. Here's
a quick run-down of what I did yesterday, on a typical day8:10—"Checked day's work schedule.
One of my new men was putting in a
buried service wire, and I went over the
job specs with him to be sure he had
things straight.
8:30 —"Answered mail while my clerk
checked time sheets from previous day.
9:30 —"Out to supervise installation of
the first aluminum Outdoor Telephone
Booth in my exchange. Reviewed the
assembly instructions with the installers,
then arranged for special tools and bolts
to be delivered to the job.

11:30 —"Drove across town. Made a
complete 'quality inspection' on a telephone we installed last week. Everything
checked O.K.
12:00 —"Lunch.
1:00 —"Picked up film for next day's
safety meeting. Watched the film, made
notes for discussion.
2:00—"Met with moving company

manager to estimate cost of telephone
cable lifting for a house moving job.
Drove the route he had planned and
worked out schedule for construction
crews.
3:30—"Returned to aluminum booth in-

stallation. Went over wiring specs with
the electrician.
4:00 —"Stopped at Central Office to
pick up next day's orders. Met installers
at garage as they checked in and assigned
next day's work."

Bill has been in his present job about a year, and is
looking forward to new responsibilities as his experience increases...as are the many young college
men who have chosen telephone careers. If you'd be
interested in a similar opportunity with a Bell telephone company... or with Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric or Sandia Corporation...see
your Placement Officer for full details.

Homewood, Baltimore, March 25, 19S(

Jay Stickmen Face W-L, Duke
In Scrimmages This Week

BIA

The Board of Intramural Athletics has installed two post
pffice boxes so that the students will have a convenient method of
giving score sheets and other information to the Board.
One of the boxes is located in the basement of Gilman Hall
next to the BIA bulletin board, and the other box is located in the
gymnasium. The Board can also be informed through PO
2345, in the new dorm.
FRATERNITY SOFTBALL

Alpha Tau Omega, led by Phil Kirol, beat Phi Epsilon Pi,
9 to 5 last week, in the fraternity softball season's opener.
Kirol had two home runs, one with the bases loaded. Herb
Cohen, with three hits in five attempts, was the standout of the
Phi Ep team.
In the other fraternity softzall game, Phi Sig walloped KA,
6 to' O. Ty Freeman, who holds Phi Sig's chances for Wittich
Trophy retirement, was in his usual fine pitching form.
INDEPENDENT SOFTBALL

Sam Hemphill's outstanding hurling led the Ding-Dongs to
victory in their first game last week, as the Ding-Dongs shut out
the Demons, 4 to 0.
In the other fraternity softball game, Phi Sig walloped KA,
hitting, one home run being included among his four safeties,
sparked the Misfits to an 11 to 1 win over the Black and Blues.
RinumualmsaTy TRACK MEET _
Jack Sutherland, president of the Spiked Shoe Society,
announced early this week the results of the Society's annual
intramural track meeet.
Lou Kady, in 11 seconds flat, won the 100-yard dash;
Robin Kaples took the 220-yard run in 24 seconds; and Pinkney
Holmes captured first placse in the 660-yard set—to in 1.34.8.
Al Hynes ran the 120-yard low hurdles in 16.4 seconds. Jack
Carloek rounded out the track events by running the mile in
5:42.8.
In the field events, Jim Love won the discus throw with a
heave of 108' 7.5"; Clayton Emory leaped five feet to win the
high jump; George Laubaek took the broad jump with an effort
of 17' 8.5"; and Love repeated in the shot put with a throw
of 36'1".

These reports are for the information of students and their advisers. An informal mark does not
become a part of the permanent
record.
A student who wishes to drop a
course should get the signatures of
the adviser, the instructor and the
Dean on a Course Change form,
then file it at the Registrar's Office.
The deadline for filing course
changes is Tuesday, April 12; the
place is the Registrar's Office,
Shriver Hall. Even though an informal F is reported a student may
drop a course on or before April
12 without penalty; a student will
receive an F if he drops a course
after April 12, whether he has
been given an Informal F or not.
Special problems should be taken
up with the adviser, the Dean or
the Registrar.
